\begin{abstract}
The analysis of signals defined over a graph is relevant in many applications, such as social and economic networks, biological networks,
and so on. A key tool introduced to analyze these signals is the so called Graph Fourier Transform (GFT). Alternative definitions of GFT have been suggested, based on the eigen-decomposition of either the graph Laplacian or adjacency matrix.
In this paper, we propose an alternative approach that builds the graph Fourier basis as the set of orthonormal signals that minimize the graph cut size. We show that this problem, although combinatorial, can be handled very efficiently through the iterative solution of a series of convex problems, by resorting to the Lov\'{a}sz extension of the cut size. The proposed approach is valid for the general case of directed graphs. Then, the approach is extended to the minimization of the balanced cut size. Even if this problem is no longer associated to a convex problem, numerical results show that the solution is very stable.
\end{abstract}

\begin{IEEEkeywords}
Graph signal processing, Total Variation, Clustering.

\section{Introduction}
Signal processing on graphs has attracted a lot of interest in the last years because of its many potential
applications, from  social and economic networks, to smart grids, gene regulatory  networks,  and so on.
Signal processing on graphs represents a promising tool for the  analysis of  complex networks, where high-dimensional data  reside on the vertices of a (weighted) graph.
Many works in the recent literature attempt to extend the classical discrete signal processing (DSP) theory from
time signals or images to signals defined over the vertices of a graph. A key tool is the so called Graph Fourier Transform (GFT),
see, e.g., \cite{Shuman2013}, \cite{Moura2014}, \cite{Pesenson2008}, \cite{Zhu2012}.
Two basic approaches have been suggested to define the GFT.
The first one is rooted on spectral graph theory, which uses the graph-Laplacian as the central
unit, see e.g. \cite{Shuman2013} and the references therein. This approach has been proposed for undirected
graphs and the Fourier basis is constituted by the eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian.
An alternative approach, proposed in \cite{Moura2013}, \cite{Moura2014} for directed graphs (or digraphs, for short), builds on the Jordan
decomposition of the adjacency matrix. This second approach is rooted on the
association of the graph adjacency matrix with the signal shift operator.

In this paper, we propose an alternative approach to identify the signal expansion basis. We assume as the optimization criterion  the minimization of the cut size, as a general way to capture clustering properties of graph signals.
Then, exploiting the sub-modularity of the cut size and using the Lov\'{a}sz extension \cite{Lovasz1983}, \cite{Bach2013} we reformulate the problem as a series of convex problems, which enable a very efficient solution, without any loss of optimality. We consider the general case of directed graphs and show how the objective function modifies in case of undirected graphs.
The method is numerically efficient and it does not incur into the numerical instabilities of
the Jordan decomposition  \cite{Golub76}. Then, to avoid the possible appearance of very small size clusters,
we consider the minimization of the {\it balanced} cut size.
Even though this problem can be no longer translated into a series of convex problems, we provide a relaxed approximated solution
that exhibits a strong numerical stability.


\section{Min-cut size and its Lov\'{a}sz extension}
In this section, we recall the definitions of cut size and Lov\'{a}sz extension, as they will form the basic tools
for our definition of GFT.
We consider a graph $\mathcal{G}=\{\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}\}$
consisting of  a set of $N$ vertices (or nodes) $\mathcal{V}=\{v_1,\ldots,v_N\}$ along with a set of edges
$\mathcal{E}=\{a_{ij}\}_{i,j \in \mathcal{V}}$, such that $a_{ij}>0$ if there is a direct link from node $j$
to node $i$ or $a_{ij}=0$, otherwise. We denote with $|\mathcal{V}|$
the cardinality of $\mathcal{V}$, i.e. the number of elements of $\mathcal{V}$.
A signal ${\mbox{\boldmath $s$}}$ on a graph $\mathcal{G}$ is defined as a mapping from the vertex set
to a complex vector of size $N=|\mathcal{V}|$, i.e. ${\mbox{\boldmath $s$}}: \mathcal{V}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$.
Let ${\mbox{\boldmath $A$}}$ denote the $N\times N$ adjacency matrix with entries the edge weights $a_{ij}$ for $i,j=1,\ldots,N$.
The  graph Laplacian is defined as ${\mbox{\boldmath $L$}}:= {\mbox{\boldmath $D$}}-{\mbox{\boldmath $A$}}$ where the input degree matrix ${\mbox{\boldmath $D$}}$ is a diagonal matrix
whose $i$th diagonal entry is $d_i={\displaystyle} \sum_j a_{ij}$.

The edge boundary of $\mathcal{S}$ is defined as the set of edges with one end in  $\mathcal{S}$ and the other end in its complement $\bar{\mathcal{S}}$.
